title: Riot isn't considerate of the time we're wasting due to trolling
body: I'm really not comprehensive of why riot consistently neglects their players in terms of those who purposely ruin the gaming experience for those who endeavor winning. I've recently orchestrated an experiment where I've created 10 different accounts, raised them all to level 30 and entered ranked. 77-100% of games engaged upon on 10 accounts (each played  25 games) Were a loss due to individuals who've either purposely destroyed the game due to not getting their lane, not getting their champion, and even because another player didn't play his/her champ the way another individual wanted them to. Majority of those games I was reported due to being camped, dived, or for no reason at all by the same people who cursed out the team, raged, and insulted anyone if not everyone.  Hopefully riot will create a more constructive way to penalize those who purposely ruin the game for others.

replies.body:
Rioter grrrlee here. I have only recently started to lurk these boards, and I can't but find it a little disheartening that so many people seem to believe we do not care about players. I have to keep reminding myself that these Boards are not the most accurate representation of the player base. (◞‸◟；)

As a part of this company, I have never felt that it has focused on anything other than Players [that means you and me]. In fact, it's the only thing in our mission statement, and a huge part of our manifesto [ see: http://www.riotgames.com/riot-manifesto ]. People here _really do_ aspire to be _player-focused_, as much as we are able. We are gamers; we play LoL often and can feel the player pain as much as the rest of you. I've been a part of companies that are driven solely by marketing -- bombarding customers with annoying promotional/sale emails, selling information to all bidders, scheming on how to milk every penny. I left my last job to come to Riot because this attitude didn't sit well with me, and I could see how it was affecting our customers. I have not once seen a major focus on eCommerce or marketing, and that is one of the things that I appreciate most about working here.

If you don't believe that we are focusing on certain issues that really matter to you, you may be right. But it's prolly because there are so many other issues jumping up all over the place. The things we choose to work on, and what we ultimately end up doing, is determined by a mixture of research, data, player feedback, and our own instincts/emotions as gamers ourselves. We cannot possibly make everyone happy about everything all at the same time, but I honestly feel that this company is approaching things as correctly as possible.

More on topic with OP: decimatetheweak, if you have documented your research, I would love to see it and even possibly share it with others here at Riot. Toxicity is something we are striving to battle better all the time, and maybe your work can help us improve. I appreciate your passion for this issue!

This is true in every aspect of our jobs, from our day to day tasks, to how we handle customer service and what we say in social media.

As I've mentioned previously, please do not take inaction to mean indifference; Rioters are players too, and we know the pain is real.

I find it really hard to believe riot really cares about the time we waste seeing as they have no solution to when someone afk/leaves or straight up trolls. The surrender vote is located at a time where the game was already decided over 5 minutes before it's possible. The surrender vote already has to have an 80% yes vote and if you don't vote your vote is automatically counted as a no instead of an absent vote as it should. When someone leaves a game I have to sit there for 20 minutes and be over punished if I dare to watch a youtube video instead of hopelessly pushing back minion waves just so I don't get banned. Why doesn't riot let us leave if someone else leaves. I don't understand why not, it's already proven to be a good system in dota and I don't see how it could be any different in league. Weather you believe me or not that the game is decided before you are allowed to surrender I find that sense the surrender vote already has a huge standard of 80% yes vote that we should be allowed to surrender earlier even if only 20% of the games are turely decided by 15 minutes.

If we knew the exactly perfect thing to do, it'd be easy to get started on it.

> Why doesn't riot let us leave if someone else leaves.

In theory that might sound amazingly simple a solution, but I can quickly think of how easily it could be misused by players who are looking for a way out of a loss. Does this help you understand how it's harder to figure out the right solution to release in the game?

Player pain -- ranging in everything from toxicity and trolling to disconnections and lag -- is a constant and serious discussion in our offices. So I hope you would truly reconsider your belief that Rioters don't care about player experiences.

> Please don't equate having no solution with not caring (´-﹏-`；) There's so much to consider when making big changes/features such as this, much more time is necessary to really investigate our options before even beginning to implement anything. If we knew the exactly perfect thing to do, it'd be easy to get started on it.

I think there is a problem with this philosophy. So many things can be done but they have some problems, there may not be a perfect solution to problems like 4v5s, but there are systems that are better. They can be exploited, but so can the current system. Riot often uses variants on this "perfect thing to do" quote to justify not improving the current system. Don't let the perfect be the enemy of improvement.

You're right, using it as an excuse would definitely be a problem. I hope nobody at Riot is claiming that it's ok to not act at all because we haven't yet found the "perfect thing to do"!

There's constantly work being done in terms of research and investigation when it comes to player behavior and toxicity. So it's not really 'inaction,' just it's mostly behind the scenes so it's harder for the general community to appreciate. I wish I could tell you what exactly is in the works, but I am not a direct part of that team.

What I really would love for players to know is that it's not that we do not care about trolls or toxicity; it's always on our minds.

Hrmm, I guess I can see your point about F2P's because of the reputation so many of them have garnered. For me, I have never been the type to pay for things in F2P's, because I'm super cheap （˶′◡‵˶） And from my own experiences, League is the only game where I didn't feel like people shelling out real monehs were getting ahead. Before I became a Rioter, I didn't spend one penny in-game because that's not my style. Instead, I appreciated that I could hoard IP to buy champs and runes. It didn't really bother me to not have pretty skins, since they gave me no real advantage during gameplay.

I suppose that's one of the things that really spoke to me about Riot Games. Unlike other F2P's I had played, Riot seemed to care first about player experience, not about forcing people to cough up cash for superior items, extended playtime, or whatever. I never even felt pressured to buy skins because there were no aggressive marketing tactics.

Maybe there are other F2P's with the same model, I'm not trying to discount them or their efforts at all. I just happen to really appreciate what I have seen Riot do, and I am happy to be a part of this team.

Did you see opportunities for PR people at Riot when you were deciding to work there? I'm thinking about going back to school for PR related stuff. Maybe I can work with you five years down the road.

One of the awesome things about this company is that we are encouraged to pursue career paths that we _want_ to be following. I have heard several stories from Rioters who were hired to do one thing, but did an overhaul to get to where they would be happier [see Christian Linke!]. We are invited and encouraged to speak with different teams and disciplines if we are curious about learning more. I super appreciate this kind of openness.

For me, this is a place that understands that work should be more than about getting through the day/week/month/year to make that paycheck. If you are happy doing your work, you're more likely to be more passionate, more thorough, more innovative, etc.

I'm on the Insights Tech team now, working with big data, but who knows where I'll end up ultimately!

And if you _do_ end up here, let's grab lunch at Noms and chat!! ヽ(´∀｀ヽ)
